text: Net income $7.4B, +19% YoY
Organic growth in all businesses
Operating leverage¹, 8th consecutive quarter
Strong balance sheet CET1 11.6%²
Robust liquidity GLS $867B³
Return on common equity 11.2%
Return on tangible common equity⁴ 15.5%
Return on average assets 0.94%
Consumer Banking: Added ~157,000 net new checking accounts; 18th consecutive quarter of growth
Consumer Banking: Added 1.2 million credit card accounts
Consumer Banking: Record 3.7 million consumer investment accounts, with $46 billion net client flows since 2Q22
Consumer Banking: Grew digital sales 8% YoY to 1.8 million; digital sales represented 51% of total sales
Global Wealth & Investment Management: Added over 12,000 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank
Global Wealth & Investment Management: $83 billion total net client flows since 2Q22
Global Wealth & Investment Management: Opened over 36,500 bank accounts, up 24% YoY
Global Wealth & Investment Management: Sent ~52,000 referrals to other lines of business
Global Banking: Added more than 1,100 new clients YTD² while deepening relationships with existing clients
Global Banking: Increased client-facing headcount by 9% since 2Q20
Global Banking: $2.9 billion Global Transaction Services revenue, up 23% YoY
Global Banking: #2 in investment banking fees; grew market share 153 bps vs. 2Q22
Global Markets: Highest first-half sales and trading revenue in over a decade
Global Markets: Record average loans of $129 billion, up 12% YoY
Global Markets: Credit trading revenue up 47% YoY in first half of 2023
Global Markets: Zero trading loss days in first half of 2023
Operating leverage is calculated as the year-over-year percentage change in revenue, net of interest expense, less the percentage change in noninterest expense.
There was a break in the operating leverage streak between 3Q19 and 2Q21.
Comparisons are to 2Q22, unless otherwise noted.
Net income of $7.4B; diluted earnings per share of $0.88; ROE 11.2%, ROTCE 15.5%.
Revenue, net of interest expense, of $25.2B increased $2.5B, or 11%.
Net interest income (NII) of $14.2B ($14.3B FTE) increased $1.7B, or 14%, driven primarily by benefits from higher interest rates and loan growth.
Noninterest income of $11.0B increased $795MM, or 8%, as higher sales and trading revenue more than offset lower service charges and investment and brokerage fees.
Provision for credit losses of $1.1B.
Net reserve build of $256MM vs. net reserve release of $48MM in 2Q22; build of $124MM in 1Q23.
Net charge-offs (NCOs) of $869MM increased compared to 2Q22 and 1Q23, and remained below pre-pandemic levels.
Net charge-off ratio of 33 bps increased 10 bps vs. 2Q22 and 1 bp vs. 1Q23.
Noninterest expense of $16.0B increased $0.8B, or 5%, vs. 2Q22, resulting in operating leverage for the eighth consecutive quarter.
The balance sheet remained strong, with average loans and leases growing by $5B from 1Q23, while average deposits decreased by $18B from 1Q23.
Common Equity Tier 1 ratio of 11.6% increased 23 bps from 1Q23.
Average Global Liquidity Sources stood at $867B.
Paid $1.8B in common dividends and repurchased $0.5B of common stock.
Announced expectation for a 9% increase in quarterly common dividend to begin in 3Q23.
EOP (end of period) basis unless noted.
CET1 ratio of 11.6% increased 23 bps vs. 1Q23.
CET1 capital of $190B increased $6B from 1Q23, driven by net income, partially offset by capital distributions to shareholders.
Standardized RWA of $1,638B increased $17B from 1Q23.
Book value per share of $32.05 improved 7% from 2Q22.
Average Global Liquidity Sources of $867B increased $13B, or 2%, from 1Q23.
Bank of America Ranked #1 in U.S. Retail Deposit Market Share¹
Deposits in excess of loans grew from $0.5T in 4Q19 to $1.1T (4Q21-1Q22) and were $0.8T at June 30, 2023.
Excess deposits are stored in cash and investment securities, with 54% in HTM (held-to-maturity) and 46% in cash and AFS (available-for-sale) at June 30, 2023.
AFS securities are substantially all hedged with floating rate swaps. The company sold $93B of securities and closed hedges in 1H23, adding the proceeds to cash.
The HTM securities book has declined quarterly since peaking at $683B in 3Q21, and is down $69B at June 30, 2023 vs. 3Q21.
HTM valuation declined by $7B in 2Q23, primarily due to higher mortgage interest rates.
Net Interest Income (excluding Global Markets) was $14.0B in 2Q23, up from a trough of $9.1B in 3Q20.
The yield on cash and securities continued to improve faster than the rate paid on total average deposits.

Net interest income of $14.2B ($14.3B FTE) increased $1.7B YoY, driven by higher interest rates, lower premium amortization expense, and loan growth, partially offset by lower average deposit balances and NII related to Global Markets activity.

NII decreased $0.3B, or 2%, from 1Q23, driven by higher deposit costs and lower balances, partially offset by higher asset yields, higher NII related to GM activity, and one additional day of interest accrual.
NII related to GM activity declined approximately $0.7B YoY and increased $0.2B from 1Q23.
Premium amortization expense was $30MM in 2Q23, compared to $34MM in 1Q23 and $584MM in 2Q22.
Net interest yield of 2.06% was impacted by higher 2Q23 average earning assets, increasing 20 bps YoY but decreasing 14 bps from 1Q23. Excluding Global Markets, the net interest yield was 2.65%.
As of June 30, 2023, a +100 bps parallel shift in the interest rate yield curve is estimated to benefit net interest income by $3.3B over the next 12 months.
Noninterest expense of $16.0B in 2Q23 included $276MM litigation expense, driven by agreements reached on consumer regulatory matters.

Noninterest expense increased $0.8B, or 5%, vs. 2Q22, driven by increased investments in the franchise across people and technology, as well as higher FDIC expense from the increased assessment on banks announced in 2022.

Noninterest expense declined $0.2B, or 1%, vs. 1Q23, driven primarily by the absence of seasonally higher payroll taxes, partially offset by the higher litigation expense ($276MM in 2Q23 vs. $89MM in 1Q23).

2H23 expense could include an accrual of approximately $1.9B upon enactment of the final FDIC special assessment rule for uninsured deposits of failed banks, if enacted consistent with the proposed rule.
Total net charge-offs of $869MM increased $62MM from 1Q23.

Consumer net charge-offs of $720MM increased $67MM, driven primarily by higher credit card losses. The credit card loss rate was 2.60% in 2Q23 vs. 2.21% in 1Q23, but remained below the pre-pandemic rate of 3.03%.
Commercial net charge-offs of $149MM decreased $5MM, as lower Commercial and Industrial net charge-offs were mostly offset by higher Commercial Real Estate net charge-offs.
The net charge-off ratio of 0.33% increased 1 bp from 1Q23 and remained below pre-pandemic levels.
Provision for credit losses was $1.1B, including a net reserve build of $256MM in 2Q23, driven primarily by credit card loan growth.
Allowance for loan and lease losses of $13.0B represented 1.24% of total loans and leases. Total allowance of $14.3B included $1.4B for unfunded commitments.
Nonperforming loans (NPLs) increased $0.2B from 1Q23 to $4.1B, with 61% of Consumer NPLs being contractually current.
Commercial reservable criticized utilized exposure of $21.5B increased $1.7B from 1Q23, driven primarily by Commercial Real Estate.
Net income of $2.9B decreased 1% from 2Q22, as strong revenue growth was offset by increased provision and noninterest expense.
Pretax, pre-provision income of $5.1B increased 21% from 2Q22.
Achieved the 9th consecutive quarter of operating leverage; efficiency ratio improved YoY to 52%.
Revenue of $10.5B improved 15% from 2Q22, due to increased NII driven by higher interest rates and loan balances, partially offset by lower service charges.
Provision for credit losses was $1.3B vs. $0.3B in 2Q22, with a net reserve build of $448MM in 2Q23 driven by credit card loan growth.
Net charge-offs of $819MM increased $317MM, driven by credit card debt.
Noninterest expense of $5.5B increased 10% from 2Q22, driven primarily by continued investments in employees and higher litigation expense.
Average deposits above $1T decreased $72B, or 7%, from 2Q22; 57% of deposits are in checking accounts and 92% are primary accounts.
Average loans and leases of $307B increased $17B, or 6%, from 2Q22.
Combined credit/debit card spend of $226B increased 3% from 2Q22, with credit up 1% and debit up 3%.
Record consumer investment assets of $387B grew $72B, or 23%, from 2Q22, driven by record $46B of client flows and higher market valuations, with 3.7MM accounts, up 10%.
10.4MM Total clients enrolled in Preferred Rewards, up 6% from 2Q22, with a 99% annualized retention rate.
Net income of $1.0B decreased 15% from 2Q22, with a pretax margin of 25% and strong organic client activity.
Revenue of $5.2B decreased 4% compared to 2Q22, as lower average equity and fixed income market levels and transactional volumes drove asset management and brokerage fees lower.
Noninterest expense of $3.9B increased 1% vs. 2Q22, as investments in the business were mostly offset by lower revenue-related incentives.
Client balances of $3.6T increased 8% from 2Q22, driven by higher market valuations and positive net client flows, including AUM flows of $14B in 2Q23.
Average deposits of $295B decreased $69B, or 19%, from 2Q22.
Average loans and leases of $219B were relatively flat to 2Q22.
Added over 12,000 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank in 2Q23 and opened over 36,500 new bank accounts.
83% of GWIM households/relationships are digitally active across the enterprise.
Net income of $2.7B increased 76% from 2Q22, with pretax, pre-provision income of $3.6B up 65%.
Revenue of $6.5B increased 29% vs. 2Q22, driven by higher NII, leasing revenue, and the absence of mark-to-market losses, partially offset by lower treasury service charges.
Total Corporation investment banking fees (excl. self-led) of $1.2B increased $0.1B, or 7%, from 2Q22, with improved market share of 153 bps and a #2 investment banking fee ranking.
Provision for credit losses of $9MM decreased $148MM vs. 2Q22, as the prior year included a reserve build.
Noninterest expense of $2.8B increased 1% from 2Q22, as continued investments were mostly offset by the absence of certain regulatory expenses.
Average deposits of $498B decreased $12B, or 2%, from 2Q22.
Average loans and leases of $383B increased $6B, or 2%, from 2Q22.
Net income of $1.1B increased 9% from 2Q22. Excluding net DVA, net income of $1.2B increased 32%.
Revenue of $4.9B increased 8% from 2Q22, driven primarily by higher sales and trading revenue and the absence of mark-to-market losses related to leveraged finance positions in 2Q22.
Sales and trading revenue of $4.3B increased 3% from 2Q22.
Fixed income, currencies, and commodities (FICC) revenue increased 7% to $2.7B, driven by strong trading performance in currencies, emerging markets interest rates, and secured financing.
Equities revenue decreased 2% to $1.6B, driven primarily by weaker trading performance in derivatives, partially offset by an increase in client financing activities.
Excluding net DVA, sales and trading revenue of $4.4B increased 10% from 2Q22. FICC revenue of $2.8B increased 18% and Equities revenue of $1.6B decreased 2%.
Noninterest expense of $3.3B increased 8% vs. 2Q22, driven by investments in the business, including people and technology, and activity-related expenses.
Average VaR of $76MM in 2Q23.
Net loss of $182MM included a $197MM pretax loss on sales of AFS debt securities.
Total corporate effective tax rate (ETR) for the quarter was 8%.
Excluding any discrete tax benefits and recurring ESG tax credit benefits, the ETR would have been approximately 26%.
Business Leadership: No. 1 in estimated U.S. Retail Deposits, Online Banking and Mobile Banking Functionality, and Small Business Lender.
Recognized as Best Bank in North America, Best Consumer Digital Bank in the U.S., and Best Bank in the U.S. for Small and Medium Enterprises.
Certified by J.D. Power for Outstanding Client satisfaction and No. 1 in Customer Satisfaction for U.S. Retail Banking Advice.
Ranked No. 1 on multiple Forbes and Barron's lists for wealth advisors.
Recognized for excellence in financial planning, personal trust, private banking, technology, and client service.
Recognized with multiple awards in 2022 and 2023, including World's Most Innovative Bank and Best Bank for various services like Digital Banking, Financing, and Cash Management.
Maintains relationships with 73% of the Global Fortune 500 and 95% of the U.S. Fortune 1,000.
Recognized as World's Best Bank for Markets and received several awards for derivatives, financing, and research in 2022 and 2023.
Commercial Real Estate loan portfolio characteristics: ~75% Class A property type, ~55% origination LTV, ~4% NPL to loans, $4.5B reservable criticized exposure, ~80% LTV, and NCOs of $71MM in 2Q23.
Global Liquidity Sources (GLS) include cash and high-quality, liquid, unencumbered securities readily available to meet funding requirements.
Reserve Build (or Release) is calculated by subtracting net charge-offs from the provision for credit losses.
Pretax, pre-provision income (PTPI) is a non-GAAP measure calculated by adjusting pretax income to add back provision for credit losses.
Interest rate sensitivity reflects the pretax impact to forecasted net interest income over the next 12 months from a parallel shock to the forward curve.
Revenue for all periods included net debit valuation adjustments (DVA) on derivatives.
VaR model uses a historical simulation approach based on three years of historical data and an expected shortfall methodology equivalent to a 99% confidence level.
(A) Estimated U.S. retail deposits based on June 30, 2022 FDIC deposit data.
(B) Javelin 2023 Online and Mobile Banking Scorecards.
(C) FDIC, 1Q23.
(D) Global Finance, March 2023.
(E) Global Finance, August 2022.
(F) Global Finance, December 2022.
(G) J.D. Power 2023 Financial Health Support CertificationSM.
(H) J.D. Power 2023 U.S. Retail Banking Advice Satisfaction Study.
(I) Industry Q1-23 FDIC call reports.
(J) Family Wealth Report, 2023.
(K) Global Private Banking Innovation Award, 2023.
(M) Euromoney, 2023.
(N) Global Finance, 2023.
(O) Global Finance Treasury & Cash Management Awards, 2023.
(P) Celent, 2023.
(Q) Global Finance Trade & Supply Chain Finance Awards, 2023.
(R) Greenwich, 2023.
(S) GlobalCapital, 2022.
(U) DealCatalyst, 2022.
(V) Institutional Investor, 2022.
(W) Refinitiv, 2023 YTD.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements which are not guarantees of future results and involve known and unknown risks and uncertainties.
Actual outcomes may differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking statements.
Investors should consider various uncertainties and risks, including litigation, regulatory actions, economic conditions, interest rates, inflation, credit losses, and geopolitical instability.

Other risks include adverse developments in the banking industry, changes in accounting standards, regulatory capital requirements, cyberattacks, climate change impacts, and other geopolitical events.
The Corporation undertakes no obligation to update any forward-looking statement.
The information presented is preliminary and based on data available at the time of the earnings presentation.
The presentation may include non-GAAP financial measures; for more information and reconciliations, refer to the quarterly earnings press release.
Key financial and nonfinancial performance indicators (KPIs) are presented to provide insight into underlying operational performance and trends.
Net interest income is also presented on a fully taxable-equivalent (FTE) basis, which is a non-GAAP measure, to allow for comparison of amounts from both taxable and tax-exempt sources.

Capital is allocated to business segments based on a methodology that considers regulatory capital requirements and internal risk-based models; this allocation was adjusted in the first quarter of 2023.
